Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: My phone buzzes just as I’m about to leave for work. It’s Jamie, my closest friend, texting, “Ugh, today’s dragging. Wish I could just talk to someone.” I know Jamie’s been having a rough time lately, and I promised I’d always be there to listen. I glance at the clock—if I don’t swing by my apartment now to grab my ID, I won’t be able to vote tomorrow. The polls are open, but today is my only window to get the ID I forgot. My chest tightens. Jamie expects me to reply, maybe even call, and I want to be the friend who listens, who’s there when it matters. But I also feel the weight of my responsibility as a voter, the importance of showing up and making my voice heard. I stare at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen, torn between the urge to support my friend and the need to fulfill my civic duty. The minutes tick by, and I can feel the pressure mounting from both sides, each expectation pulling me in a different direction.
